trans-unit.source: Using the Azure Service Bus Connector in Logic Apps | Microsoft Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure Service Bus Connector in Logic Apps | Microsoft Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: How to create and configure the Azure Service Bus Connector or API app and use it in a logic app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: How to create and configure the Azure Service Bus Connector or API app and use it in a logic app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Get started with the Azure Service Bus Connector and add it to your Logic App
trans-unit.target: Get started with the Azure Service Bus Connector and add it to your Logic App

trans-unit.source: Connect to Azure Service Bus to send messages to Queues and Topics and receive messages from Queues and Subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Connect to Azure Service Bus to send messages to Queues and Topics and receive messages from Queues and Subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Connectors are used in Logic Apps as a part of a "workflow".
trans-unit.target: Connectors are used in Logic Apps as a part of a "workflow".

trans-unit.source: Triggers and Actions
trans-unit.target: Triggers and Actions

trans-unit.source: Triggers are events that happen.
trans-unit.target: Triggers are events that happen.

trans-unit.source: For example, when an order is updated or when a new customer is added.
trans-unit.target: For example, when an order is updated or when a new customer is added.

trans-unit.source: An Action is the result of the trigger.
trans-unit.target: An Action is the result of the trigger.

trans-unit.source: For example, when an order or a new message is put in a queue, send an alert or a message.
trans-unit.target: For example, when an order or a new message is put in a queue, send an alert or a message.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Service Bus Connector can be used as a trigger or an action in a logic app and supports data in JSON and XML formats.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Service Bus Connector can be used as a trigger or an action in a logic app and supports data in JSON and XML formats.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Service Bus Connector has the following Triggers and Actions available:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Service Bus Connector has the following Triggers and Actions available:

trans-unit.source: Triggers
trans-unit.target: Triggers

trans-unit.source: Actions
trans-unit.target: Actions

trans-unit.source: Message Available
trans-unit.target: Message Available

trans-unit.source: Send message
trans-unit.target: Send message

trans-unit.source: Create the Azure Service Bus connector
trans-unit.target: Create the Azure Service Bus connector

trans-unit.source: A connector can be created within a logic app or be created directly from the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: A connector can be created within a logic app or be created directly from the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: To create a connector from the Marketplace:
trans-unit.target: To create a connector from the Marketplace:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure startboard, select **Marketplace**.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure startboard, select **Marketplace**.

trans-unit.source: Search for “Azure Service Bus connector”, select it, and select **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Search for “Azure Service Bus connector”, select it, and select **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Enter the Name, App Service Plan, and other properties:
trans-unit.target: Enter the Name, App Service Plan, and other properties:

trans-unit.source: Enter the following package settings:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following package settings:

trans-unit.source: Name | Description
trans-unit.target: Name | Description

trans-unit.source: Connection String | The connection string for Azure Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: Connection String | The connection string for Azure Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: For example, enter: *Endpoint=sb://[namespace].servicebus.windows.net;SharedAccessKeyName=[name];SharedAccessKey=[key]*.
trans-unit.target: For example, enter: *Endpoint=sb://[namespace].servicebus.windows.net;SharedAccessKeyName=[name];SharedAccessKey=[key]*.

trans-unit.source: Entity Name | Enter the name of the Queue or Topic.
trans-unit.target: Entity Name | Enter the name of the Queue or Topic.

trans-unit.source: Subscription Name | Enter the name of the Subscription to receive messages from.
trans-unit.target: Subscription Name | Enter the name of the Subscription to receive messages from.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Using the Service Bus Connector in your Logic App
trans-unit.target: Using the Service Bus Connector in your Logic App

trans-unit.source: Once your connector is created, you can now use the Azure Service Bus connector as a trigger or action for your Logic App.
trans-unit.target: Once your connector is created, you can now use the Azure Service Bus connector as a trigger or action for your Logic App.

trans-unit.source: To do this:
trans-unit.target: To do this:

trans-unit.source: Create a new Logic App and choose the same resource group that has the Azure Service Bus Connector:
trans-unit.target: Create a new Logic App and choose the same resource group that has the Azure Service Bus Connector:

trans-unit.source: Open “Triggers and Actions” to open the Logic Apps designer and configure your workflow:
trans-unit.target: Open “Triggers and Actions” to open the Logic Apps designer and configure your workflow:

trans-unit.source: The Azure Service Bus connector appears in the “API Apps in this resource group” section in the gallery on the right hand side:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Service Bus connector appears in the “API Apps in this resource group” section in the gallery on the right hand side:

trans-unit.source: You can drop the Azure Service Bus Connector into the editor by clicking on the “Azure Service Bus Connector”.
trans-unit.target: You can drop the Azure Service Bus Connector into the editor by clicking on the “Azure Service Bus Connector”.

trans-unit.source: You can now use Azure Service Bus connector in the workflow.
trans-unit.target: You can now use Azure Service Bus connector in the workflow.

trans-unit.source: You can use the message retrieved from the Azure Service Bus trigger ("Message Available") in other actions in the flow:
trans-unit.target: You can use the message retrieved from the Azure Service Bus trigger ("Message Available") in other actions in the flow:

trans-unit.source: You can also use the Azure Service Bus "Send Message" action:
trans-unit.target: You can also use the Azure Service Bus "Send Message" action:

trans-unit.source: Do more with your Connector
trans-unit.target: Do more with your Connector

trans-unit.source: Now that the connector is created, you can add it to a business workflow using a Logic App.
trans-unit.target: Now that the connector is created, you can add it to a business workflow using a Logic App.

trans-unit.source: See [What are Logic Apps?](app-service-logic-what-are-logic-apps.md).
trans-unit.target: See [What are Logic Apps?](app-service-logic-what-are-logic-apps.md).

trans-unit.source: View the Swagger REST API reference at [Connectors and API Apps Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=529766).
trans-unit.target: View the Swagger REST API reference at [Connectors and API Apps Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=529766).

trans-unit.source: You can also review performance statistics and control security to the connector.
trans-unit.target: You can also review performance statistics and control security to the connector.

trans-unit.source: See [Manage and Monitor your built-in API Apps and Connectors](app-service-logic-monitor-your-connectors.md).
trans-unit.target: See [Manage and Monitor your built-in API Apps and Connectors](app-service-logic-monitor-your-connectors.md).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
